articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Takes a Step to the Left on Health Care
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton, moving in Bernie Sanders’s direction, came out this week in favor of “the public option,” or allowing people to buy into Medicare.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton, moving in Bernie Sanders’s direction, came out this week in favor of “the public option,” or allowing people to buy into Medicare.
articles.lead_paragraph: For months during the Democratic presidential nominating contest, Hillary Clinton has resisted calls from Senator Bernie Sanders to back a single-payer health system, arguing that the fight for government-run health care was a wrenching legislative battle that had already been lost.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Margot Sanger-Katz

articles.headline: It’s a Tough Job Market for the Young Without College Degrees
articles.snippet: A national study shows that high school graduates often struggle to find work. Their jobless rate is 17.8 percent, and it’s much worse for dropouts.
articles.abstract: A national study shows that high school graduates often struggle to find work. Their jobless rate is 17.8 percent, and it’s much worse for dropouts.
articles.lead_paragraph: For seniors graduating from the University of Michigan this month, employers have been lining up since the fall to offer interviews and boast of their companies’ benefits. Recruiters would ask when their competitors were coming, said Geni Harclerode, the university’s assistant director of employer development, and then they’d say: “Well, we want to come the week before.”

articles.headline: Rodrigo Duterte’s Many Sides: Brash and Crude or Tough and Shrewd
articles.snippet: As Mr. Duterte appears poised to become the country’s next president, people who know him well say the depiction of him as a crass vigilante is an oversimplification.
articles.abstract: As Mr. Duterte appears poised to become the country’s next president, people who know him well say the depiction of him as a crass vigilante is an oversimplification.
articles.lead_paragraph: DAVAO CITY, Philippines — Jess Saplala was sitting in a bar late one night in Davao City listening to a man singing a Frank Sinatra ballad, when he noticed that the crooner was none other than the town’s mayor, Rodrigo Duterte.
articles.byline: By Floyd Whaley and Richard C. Paddock

articles.headline: ‘Contract for Deed’ Lending Gets Federal Scrutiny
articles.snippet: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is investigating the mortgage financing model that is viewed by many as often harmful for low-income buyers.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is investigating the mortgage financing model that is viewed by many as often harmful for low-income buyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A revival in seller-financed home sales aimed at people who cannot qualify for a mortgage has started to attract scrutiny from the nation’s top consumer watchdog.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Puerto Rico’s Fiscal Fiasco Is a Harbinger of Mainland Woes
articles.snippet: Illinois, New Jersey, Philadelphia, St. Louis and other states and cities are under dark financial clouds brought on by deferring costs for decades.
articles.abstract: Illinois, New Jersey, Philadelphia, St. Louis and other states and cities are under dark financial clouds brought on by deferring costs for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: To tourists, Puerto Rico means piña coladas and sunbathing. To Puerto Ricans, it looks very different: The unemployment rate is over 12 percent, schools and hospitals are closing, and the government debt is so huge it makes Detroit’s look modest.

articles.headline: Senator Demands Answers From Facebook on Claims of ‘Trending’ List Bias
articles.snippet: John Thune, Republican chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, wants a response to a report that Facebook suppressed conservative articles.
articles.abstract: John Thune, Republican chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, wants a response to a report that Facebook suppressed conservative articles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee demanded on Tuesday that Facebook explain how it handles news articles in its “trending” list, responding to a report that staff members had intentionally suppressed articles from conservative sources.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Transgender Fight in North Carolina May Hinge On 1964 Law
articles.snippet: The Civil Rights Act prohibits discrimination because of “race, color, religion, sex or national origin,” but the word sex made it into the bill almost accidentally.
articles.abstract: The Civil Rights Act prohibits discrimination because of “race, color, religion, sex or national origin,” but the word sex made it into the bill almost accidentally.
articles.lead_paragraph: The legal battle over which bathrooms transgender people can use in North Carolina turns on a deceptively simple question: Can a law, written in the heat of the civil rights movement generations ago, apply to people the drafters never intended to cover?
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Tamar Lewin

articles.headline: Use of Unclassified Email Systems Not Limited to Clinton
articles.snippet: A review of tens of thousands of documents reveals that sending sensitive information on unclassified computer networks was not limited to Hillary Clinton.
articles.abstract: A review of tens of thousands of documents reveals that sending sensitive information on unclassified computer networks was not limited to Hillary Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the morning of March 13, 2011, the assistant secretary of state for Near Eastern affairs, Jeffrey D. Feltman, wrote an urgent email to more than two dozen colleagues informing them that Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates were sending troops into Bahrain to put down antigovernment protests there.

articles.headline: Obama’s Visit Raises Ghosts of Hiroshima
articles.snippet: Most people in Japan believe the city was a victim of unnecessary brutality, but for Americans of the World War II generation, Hiroshima is at the center of a very different narrative.
articles.abstract: Most people in Japan believe the city was a victim of unnecessary brutality, but for Americans of the World War II generation, Hiroshima is at the center of a very different narrative.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, visitors to the ghostly dome in Hiroshima that stands like a sole survivor from the dropping of the atomic bomb there more than 70 years ago entered a world that mixed unspeakable tragedy with historical amnesia.

articles.headline: Facebook’s Bias Is Built-In, and Bears Watching
articles.snippet: Its algorithms are as infused with bias as any human decision, but neither it nor its audience thinks of Facebook as a news organization with editorial responsibilities.
articles.abstract: Its algorithms are as infused with bias as any human decision, but neither it nor its audience thinks of Facebook as a news organization with editorial responsibilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook is the world’s most influential source of news.

articles.headline: Donald Trump, Bucking Calls to Unite, Claims ‘Mandate’ to Be Provocative
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump said his supporters wanted him to run as a fiery outsider rather than embrace the mellower approach Republican leaders want.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump said his supporters wanted him to run as a fiery outsider rather than embrace the mellower approach Republican leaders want.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s behavior in recent days — the political threats to the House speaker, Paul D. Ryan; the name-calling on Twitter; the attacks on Hillary Clinton’s marriage — has deeply puzzled Republicans who expected him to move to unite the party, start acting presidential and begin courting the female voters he will need in the general election.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Maggie Haberman
